conclusion: The cyclic process is A→B→C→A.
The work done by the gas during a process is given by the area under the curve on the P-V diagram.
For a cyclic process, the net work done is the area enclosed by the cycle.
The cycle A→B→C→A forms a triangle on the P-V diagram.
The work done by the gas is the area enclosed by the triangle, and its sign depends on the direction of the cycle.
A clockwise cycle means positive work done by the gas, and a counterclockwise cycle means negative work done by the gas.
The arrows in the diagram indicate a clockwise cycle.
We can calculate the work done in each process and sum them up.
Process A→B is an isochoric process with constant volume V_A = V_B = 2 L.
The work done in process A→B is W_{AB} = 0.
Process B→C is a straight line from (V_B, p_B) = (2 L, 4 × 10^5 Pa) to (V_C, p_C) = (5 L, 1 × 10^5 Pa).
The work done in process B→C is the area under the curve BC, which is a trapezoid.
Process C→A is an isobaric process with constant pressure p_C = p_A = 1 × 10^5 Pa.
The work done in process C→A is W_{CA} = p_A * (V_A - V_C) = -300 J.
The total work done by the gas during the cyclic process is W_{cycle} = W_{AB} + W_{BC} + W_{CA} = 450 J.
Alternatively, the work done is the area of the triangle ABC.
Base AC is from V=2 to V=5 at p=1 × 10^5 Pa.
Length of base is 3 L = 3 × 10^{-3} m^3.
Height is the difference in pressure between B and the base, p_B - p_A = 3 × 10^5 Pa.
